frame.name: Gradable_proximity
frame.definition: <def-root>A <fen>Figure</fen> is (stably) located with respect to a <fen>Ground</fen> in terms of how the distance between them compares to some general or contextually relevant scale. The Degree of divergence from the expected distance may also be expressed. In addition to the asymmetrical consideration of <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen>, these may be construed collectively as <fen>Figures</fen>, in which case each entity is assessed for how expected its distance is from others in the group of <fen>Figures</fen>. <ex></ex> Productive metaphors include cases where the degree of closeness or intimacy between people/entities is conceptualized as gradable proximity ("their <t>close</t> / <t>distant</t> relationship..."). The directness of familial relations is also construed this way ("a <t>close</t> / <t>distant</t> cousin"). Other metaphors involve possibility - usually of more extreme events - as proximity ("it was <t>near</t> collapse / extinction / disaster") and of category fit as proximity ("that was <t>far</t> from perfection / the truth / a miracle"). </def-root>

FE.name: Ground
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Ground</fen> serves as a basis for describing the location of the <fen>Figure</fen>.
<ex>The cat is <t>near</t> <fex name="Grnd">the mat</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figure
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figure</fen> is perceived as located relative to a certain <fen>Ground</fen> location. The figure can be an entity or an event.
<ex><fex name="Fig">The cat</fex> is <t>near</t> the mat.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Accessibility
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Accessibility</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and some reference location (generally, the deictic center or the <fen>Ground</fen>). <ex>The cat is <fex name="Acc">right</fex> <t>near</t> the table.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Direction
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Direction</fen> from a reference location (generally, the deictic center) of a path to the <fen>Figure</fen>. <ex>The cat was <fex name="Dir">down</fex> <t>near</t> its food bowl .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time
FE.definition:
<def-root>The period of time during which the locative relation between <fen>Figure</fen> and <fen>Ground</fen> obtains.
<ex>He was <t>near</t> Athens <fex name="tim">on Friday</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Figures
FE.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Figures</fen> are items which mutually serve to identify the location of the other items.
<ex><fex name="Figures">The two waffle houses</fex> are so <t>close</t> together they can throw ingredients across the road to each other .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition:
<def-root>An assessment of how the distance between the <fen>Figure</fen> and the <fen>Ground</fen> diverges from expectation.
<ex>We 're <fex name="Degree">very</fex> <t>close</t> to the treasure .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Deixis
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how the locative phrase relates to the grounding of the speech situation, either locating it near (here) or far (there, yonder), or specifically separated from the speech context by distance or a barrier (over). Fillers of this FE are restricted to this closed class of items.
<ex>She has a boyfriend way <fex name="Deixis">over</fex> <t>in</t> Springfield .</ex> <ex>It is lying <fex name="Deixis">here</fex> <t>on</t> my desk .</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Directness
FE.definition:
<def-root>An indication of how closely the position of <fen>Figure</fen> matches the prototype expected from the image schema associated with the target. This FE is normally filled by closed-class, dedicated adverbs like right, straight, directly, and due (and some combinations of these), but also occurs with rarer items like 'smack dab'.
<ex>It landed <fex name="Directness">right</fex> <t>near</t> the pole .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Temporal_profile
FE.definition:
<def-root>A description of how the access path to the <fen>Ground</fen> interacts with time. This FE is filled only by the closed class of adverbials back.adv (which indicates that the position was occupied by the <fen>Figure</fen> before) and on.adv (which indicates a continued path). While this FE in its most basic use refers to cases of actual motion, it can be used with descriptions of static position, in which case it either refers to fictive, imagined motion (as in the first example below), or it backgrounds motion entirely (as in the second example).
<ex>You 'll find it straight <fex name="Temporal_profile">on</fex> over <t>near</t> the closet.</ex> <ex>He's already <fex name="Temporal_profile">back</fex> <t>near</t> the house.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Distance
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Distance</fen> between the <fen>Figure</fen> and the <fen>Ground</fen>. This FE requires an image schema with a vector that extends from the <fen>Ground</fen>, or a subpart of the <fen>Ground</fen>, in some direction, and the <fen>Distance</fen> is measured along this vector from the <fen>Ground</fen> to the profiled region.
<ex>The island was <fex name="Distance">30 miles</fex> <t>distant</t> from the mainland.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: close.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: within a very short distance.

lexUnit.name: proximity.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the state of being within a short distance (of).

lexUnit.name: far.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: not within a certain distance (of).

lexUnit.name: distant.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: not within a certain distance (of).
